What is your overall assessment of this course
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor
The primary instructor's provided students with helpful and timely feedback
The instructor established a positive learning environment
The instructor raised questions or problems that encouraged me to think critically
Comments_Questions: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course
Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved
Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
How would you summarize this course for a fellow student?  Would you recommend it to another student?  Why or why not
Comments_List: Not much honestly, maybe an hour or two at most doing the simple readings.

Strengths: very interesting material, incredible instructor, engaged students.

Weaknesses: could use slightly more directed case discussions
great
Awesome class! Loved the smaller class size which promoted a lot of good discussions.

I really enjoyed 576. I think the strengths of the course are how discussions are led in class. The flow of discussion is very natural and Professor Ndumele really helps the discussion along in the correct direction while also allowing us freedom to dictate what thoughts and specifics are engaged with. I don't really think there are any weaknesses. I think it could be improved by maybe incorporating more case studies as I really enjoyed that portion of the course.
Great course!
I really enjoyed the case studies. It would be nice to focus more heavily on those!

Strengths: Lectures are interesting and Chima is very engaging, the coursework isn't too heavy but is still enough to apply the material in a just way. 

Weaknesses: the case studies didn't really seem that relevant to the material and could've just been glanced over.

I would say that this course is the best class I've taken at Yale in terms of bang for my buck--the workload was actually less than other classes, but I feel like I learned more than just about any other course I've had. As an HCM student, we didn't have a true capstone this year, but this class felt like the perfect culmination of the last two years of learning. From the theoretical frameworks discussed at the beginning of the semester to the more practical case discussions at the close, I feel much more prepared to engaged in conversations about health systems and possible reforms thanks to this class.

To be honest, the final assignment probably should have been individual, but given the many springtime obligations of second-years, I was very grateful that it was a group assignment. The data assignment was very reasonable, but I'm not sure it was much of a value add (though seeing different data source options was helpful). I also actually liked having the midterm as an excuse to review the theory-based first half of the semester.

One possible area for improvement is that I would find it helpful to have a slightly more organized Canvas page from the beginning of the semester. It's helpful to have all assignments and due dates visible from the start, as well as having the readings and slides labeled and filed by week.
Fantastic course. I love how this course is class discussion based.

The class was amazing mainly because it was taught by Chima. This year we had a much smaller class size than usual, which made the class a lot better and more engaging. I would have liked if we did more case studies since I feel like that's how I best learned and was able to grasp the material.

I think some of the units were a little too similar, I think it would have also been nice to focus entire classes breaking down specific HC systems in different nations.  When I signed up I was really interested in socialized HC systems the US could look at, but we didn't learn much about that.

Strengths: Very engaging, knows his stuff, fun, sets realistic expectations, leads discussion well.

Weaknesses: could set better direction on the case studies and summarize key takeaways

Professor Ndumele is very nice to his students. He raised questions or problems that encouraged us to think critically. Besides, he provided every student with helpful and timely feedback about the group project.
Amazing professor! Chima is so funny and engaging, and makes the material interesting. He is also very laid back and approachable, which makes everyone feel comfortable participating.

Professor Ndumele was great. He really allowed us the freedom of creating our own discussion and only guiding it. I think time management was a weakness from time to time as we spent a lot of time on discussion and relatively less on lecture slides. I think that was just an inevitable tradeoff with having free discussion though.
Great environment to learn
Chima was my faculty advisor and certainly did not disappoint as a professor! He is funny, engaging, and tries to make the class as interactive as possible.
Chima is a great professor who is very down to Earth which makes speaking in class very easy, which I very much appreciate because I feel like class is a conversation and not a lecture.

Professor Ndumele is probably the best discussion facilitator I have encountered at Yale. He simultaneously makes everyone feel comfortable participating in class and offering contrarian or uncertain ideas, but also pushes back and makes you defend your position and analyze the assumptions baked into it. Becky and Kaitlin were also fantastic, and there help, especially with specific assignments, was greatly appreciated.

Excellent. I would not change anything. Professor Ndumele creates a fantastic learning environment, encourages discussion and debate, allows diverse viewpoints to be considered and pushes our assumptions in a great way.

Chima is the funniest teacher at YSPH and is so incredibly chill. He made the class very relaxing and I never felt like I had to worry about it. He also was very receptive and response to students' opinions. In class, if someone said something interesting, he would challenge us to think about it further. He kept the class incredibly engaging.

Chima has such great enthusiasm and knowledge. The way he ran the class encouraged a great deal of interesting discussion. The only thing I'd say is that the class wasn't very challenging and didn't push me too much.
Amazing, one of the best at my time at Yale.
great
Essential course for any health policy students pursuing the global health concentration.
I would summarize this course as an analysis of the decision-making processes that create health systems. I would definitely recommend it to another student.
definitely a must-take
I would definitely recommend this course, and actually think it should be required for the HCM curriculum (or at least elements of it incorporated into the new capstone).

The course material is incredibly interesting especially for those interested in global health and learning about how to make cross-country comparisons. A lot of what was learned in class was fundamental theories of health care and while the material could be a bit abstract at some points, it definitely provides a base of understanding for practical application.
Yeah I'd recommend it, but only if you're not familiar with international systems.
